head.title: Marbury Leads Lincoln To P.S.A.L. Championship

hedline.hl1: Marbury Leads Lincoln To P.S.A.L. Championship

block.p: Stephon Marbury was mobbed by his teammates yesterday after Lincoln's stirring 61-56 victory over Robeson at Madison Square Garden in the Public Schools Athletic League A championship game between the Brooklyn schools.
"I've got everything now," screamed Marbury, who won his first title. "I've got everything now."

Stephon Marbury was mobbed by his teammates yesterday after Lincoln's stirring 61-56 victory over Robeson at Madison Square Garden in the Public Schools Athletic League A championship game between the Brooklyn schools.
"I've got everything now," screamed Marbury, who won his first title. "I've got everything now."
The scene was starkly different from last year, when Marbury was sprawled on the court and crying after shooting 5 of 24 in losing to Martin Luther King in the final.

Marbury scored a game-high 26 points to lead the Railsplitters (24-3), who had lost in the final the last two years, before a crowd of 8,842, including Georgia Tech Coach Bobby Cremins. Marbury will attend Georgia Tech next season.

Marbury hit two free throws to give top-seeded Lincoln a 59-56 lead with 11 seconds remaining. Todd Myles, who helped Robeson win last year's B championship at the buzzer, missed a 3-pointer with 5 seconds left.
"It took three years," said Marbury, who hit 10 of 13 free throws yesterday. "We always came up short. This year we came up big."
Lincoln faced an imposing frontcourt with an average height of 6 feet 8 inches, while the Railsplitters' tallest player was 6-6 Jamel Thomas.

Gerald Hawkins (21 points) took advantage of dismal shooting (36 percent) by third-seeded Robeson (20-7, 12-1). Many of his points were on the fast break off long outlets from Thomas, who grabbed a game-high 17 rebounds.
"Jamel has played like this throughout the playoffs," said Lincoln Coach Bobby Hartstein, whose teams have been to the final 7 of the last 10 years, winning in 1986 and 1991.

With 7:15 left in the game, Marbury made a 3-pointer to tie the score at 40-40. Then Hawkins made a free throw after being fouled on a fast-break layup to give Lincoln a 41-40 lead it never relinquished.
Shamel Jones had a team-high 17 points and 4 blocks and Jameel Watkins had 12 rebounds and 4 blocks for Robeson.
In the P.S.A.L. B championship, Francis Lewis of Queens defeated Theodore Roosevelt of the Bronx, 63-58.
Hannibal Bates of Francis Lewis sat by himself in a corner of the locker room, clutching his trophy as tears streamed down his face.

"For 17 years, all I thought about was getting on a team and going to the Garden," said the 5-11 junior guard, his voice barely audible. "We wanted to represent our school and our borough. We had to come through." Bates came through, scoring a game-high 22 points.

Despite having no player over 6-3, the Rough Riders (21-3, 15-2) used their quickness to move to within 57-55 with about a minute left. But they missed 3 of 6 free throws in the last 43 seconds, while Bates made 3 of 4 free throws to clinch the game for Lewis (23-3, 15-0).

In the P.S.A.L. girls championship, Manhattan Center put a halt to A. Philip Randolph's Cinderella-like run through the playoffs with a 34-27 victory. "I knew they would come as tough as they did," said Manhattan Center Coach Varleton McDonald, referring to Randolph's players. "We're used to scoring 60 and 70 points a game."
The sixth-seeded Cougars (20-6, 10-5) -- who have no seniors -- earned their first final appearance ever by stunning second-seeded King, 40-39, last Sunday.
Jaywana Bradley of Manhattan Center (27-3, 13-3) scored a game-high 15 points.
